From a young age, John was fascinated by the world of entertainment and began his acting career in the late 1960s, appearing in various television shows and films.

His portrayal of the lovable and awkward chef earned him widespread critical acclaim and a devoted fan base. The show ran for eight seasons and cemented Ritter's status as a beloved television personality.

In addition to his work on "Three's Company", Ritter appeared in numerous other television shows and films, including "Hooperman", "8 Simple Rules", and "Sling Blade". He was also a talented voice actor and lent his voice to several animated films and television shows.

Throughout his career, Ritter received numerous award nominations, including an Emmy Award nomination for his work on "Three's Company". He was also honored with a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame in 1983.

Born in Burbank, California, Ritter grew up in a family of entertainers. His parents, Tex Ritter and Florence Ford, were both actors, and his uncle, Roy Ritter, was a musician. Ritter's early interest in acting led him to attend the University of Southern California (USC), where he studied theater and later earned a Bachelor's degree in Fine Arts.

Ritter began his acting career in the 1970s, landing small roles in various TV shows and films, including the sitcom "The Bob Newhart Show" and the film "Stay Tuned." His breakthrough came in 1976 with the popular sitcom "Three's Company," where he played Jack Tripper, a lovable and clumsy chef living with two female roommates. The show ran for eight seasons and earned Ritter multiple award nominations, including an Emmy Award for Outstanding Continuing or Single Performance by a Supporting Actor.

Throughout the 1980s and 1990s, Ritter continued to appear in various TV shows and films, including "Hooperman," "Problem Child," and "Clifford the Big Red Dog." He also worked as a director, directing several episodes of TV shows like "Hooperman" and "8 Simple Rules," a sitcom he starred in from 2002 until his death in 2003.

Ritter's personal life was marked by his marriage to actress Amy Yasbeck, whom he met on the set of "Problem Child." The couple had two children, Carly and Jason.

Sadly, John Ritter passed away on September 11, 2003, at the age of 54, due to an aortic dissection. His untimely death was met with widespread grief and tributes from the entertainment industry and fans around the world.

Despite his passing, John Ritter's legacy lives on through his iconic roles and beloved sitcoms, which continue to entertain audiences to this day.
